cluster_relations.rel_desc: The size of black holes is typically quantified using the Schwarzschild radius.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Subject quantity is operationally measured or quantified using the object measure, scale, or parameter.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Schwarzschild radius is defined as the radius where the escape velocity has a specific value.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Subject concept is defined in terms of, or via, the object condition or defining relation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: escape velocity equals the speed of light

remarks: Condition further refined in next relation to specify equality with speed of light.
Condition further refined in next relation to specify equality with speed of light.
Condition further refined in next relation to specify equality with speed of light.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: At the Schwarzschild radius, the escape velocity is equal to the speed of light.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two physical quantities have equal numerical value or magnitude under the stated conditions.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Schwarzschild radius is a characteristic radius associated with a black hole.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a defining or characteristic quantity, property, or feature of the object.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Schwarzschild radius is the characteristic radius associated with a black hole beyond which escape is impossible.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Subject radius is the characteristic or defining radius associated with the object, often marking a physical or conceptual boundary.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: where escape velocity equals the speed of light
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: BoundaryType: effective outer boundary of the black hole

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Schwarzschild radius marks where the gravitational pull becomes strong enough to prevent escape.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject specifies or marks the threshold or boundary at which a particular physical effect or condition (described by the object) becomes operative or qualitatively changes.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: gravitational pull of a black hole

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: escape velocity reaches speed of light

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stephen Hawking made his prediction about Hawking radiation in the year 1974.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (often an event, action, or person-in-context) is associated with the specified calendar year.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject radius is the characteristic or defining boundary radius of the object, typically marking a limit beyond which a key physical property (such as escape) qualitatively changes.
args.justification: This relation instance focuses on the Schwarzschild radius as a defining boundary beyond which escape is impossible, i.e., a physical limit/threshold of the black hole rather than a generic measurement operation. Using rel_cls 'characteristic_boundary_relation' and rel_cls_group 'CONSTRAINT' better captures its role as a boundary/limit, instead of the previous 'measurement_relation' under 'MEASUREMENT'. The canonical name itself is already appropriate and is retained, but its description is refined to emphasize its boundary/limit semantics.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject radius is the characteristic or defining boundary radius of the object, typically marking a limit beyond which a key physical property (such as escape) qualitatively changes.
executed_decisions.justification: This relation instance focuses on the Schwarzschild radius as a defining boundary beyond which escape is impossible, i.e., a physical limit/threshold of the black hole rather than a generic measurement operation. Using rel_cls 'characteristic_boundary_relation' and rel_cls_group 'CONSTRAINT' better captures its role as a boundary/limit, instead of the previous 'measurement_relation' under 'MEASUREMENT'. The canonical name itself is already appropriate and is retained, but its description is refined to emphasize its boundary/limit semantics.
